page.title: 16HALTON CHURCH.
page.content: When we went to Halton Church we saw that the tower looked much older than the rest of the church. This is because the tower is of Norman age whereas the church was rebuilt in 1793 and again in 1876. In the graveyard there is a sundial which was made in 1635. There is also a cross in the churchyard which has carvings telling a Viking legend on two sides, with Christian inscriptions on the other two sides. Clearly it must date from a time when both these cultures were present in the area. There are fragments of Anglo-Saxon crosses preserved inside the church. The tower was built in the early 14th century. There is only one bell which is working in the Church and the other two don't work. The bells were made in 1956. The oldest recognisable gravestone dates from 1611
